sen.e: In the early Heian period, like Ki clan, Tomo was considered as the clan to pass down the ancient practices of the warriors, but, as the samurai gained power, Tomo clan faded from political limelight and after that, TOMO no Tadakuni became the first Shinto priest of Tsurugaoka Hachiman-gu Shrine, then the bloodline was inherited as the job was passed on to the generations.

In the early Heian period, the Tomo clan, like the Ki clan, was considered to be the clan that carried the ancient practices of warriors, but as the samurai gained power, the Tomo clan's political influence faded. TOMO no Tadakuni became the first Shinto priest of Tsurugaoka Hachiman-gu Shrine, and the bloodline was thereafter inherited as the job was passed on through generations.

sen.j: 受領（国司）から地方に土着し、武士団化した氏族も各地に残っている。
sen.e: Some clans have still remained in various locations since they settled down there after they were appointed to Zuryo (provincial governor) and changed to the groups of warriors.
